title: Swiss central banker Schlegel says negative rates needed to make franc unattractive
text:
A waitress presents a plate with various Swiss Franc coins and notes in this picture illustration in a restaurant in Zurich, Switzerland, May 21, 2013. REUTERS/Michael Buholzer/Illustration/File Photo

ZURICH (Reuters) - The Swiss National Bank remains committed to negative interest rates despite increasing criticism of the measure brought in to ward off interest in the Swiss franc, said Martin Schegel, a member of the central bank’s expanded governing board.

The SNB’s monetary policy was based on negative interest rates — currently -0.75% — and a readiness to intervene in the currency markets as necessary, he told an event in Zurich on Tuesday.

“We hear a lot criticism about negative interest rates. We think they are essential,” Schlegel said, adding they were “central” to keeping the franc unattractive.

The Swiss franc rose in value in July and August as the U.S. Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank announced looser policy, he said.
